pros: Leadership is top notch and really care about you as a person
cons: Corporate office is not really centralized

review_title: I loved it until I got a new manager
pros: The hours are not too late and you can work three full days and get your 40hrs in for the week.
cons: Sometimes they don’t approve overtime, sometimes you work alone all day, no lunch break. Not flexible with schedule.

job_title: X-ray Technologist LMRT in Friendswood, TX
pros: Opportunity for OT, Different insurance plans, every day could be different, time off isn’t really denied, rotating weekends, if you and your coworkers are on the same page you’re schedule could be picture perfect so you don’t feel overworked but you still get your hours.
cons: Hours can be cut depending on time of the year (like when flu season in over), could be short staffed on short notice, some coworkers are lazy and doing help the day go by, I wouldn’t work this job if you have young children or a family that values your time. A lot of people quit. There isn’t opportunity for raises

review_title: CareNow - only good for a temporary stop between real jobs.
job_title: Physician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Most co-workers in non management positions are genuinely good people and great to work with. Many were in their first healthcare related job, and were open to learning. For a clock in and out job it is acceptable. Just don’t put anything more into it, because corporate doesn’t care about even the best doctor.
cons: It felt like the “bonus” system was rigged to extract the maximal effort from the providers and staff while minimizing actual payout. In the end it is only a dead end low paying job, Little room for growth, professional independence or respect. I would only recommend it as a side moonlighting job.

pros: This location has always had fantastic direct management. Truly advocates for staff needs. Other management is easy to reach, big movement to Webex has helped with that. Shifts are flexible as long as you get it covered by someone. Its a good and flexible job for college but not as a long term solution.
cons: As a company on the whole, pay discrepancy has been an ongoing issue. I dont see that being resolved any time soon. Been there 5 years and im at $16 while some new hires are at $18. Inadequate traing time for all staff, you get maybe 2 weeks then you're expected to do it all.

review_title: Just Stay Away- This Is Not St David’s Quality
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Austin, TX
pros: 12 hr shifts Tiffs treats cookies
cons: Management is deceptive and uncaring. The AM, APM, clinic managers are all in cahoots with each other to get the most out of you with the lowest pay. They will try to convince you that HCA doesn’t want you to have even snacks or water and they are looking out for you. They will tell you not to discuss your pay (illegally) so you don’t know that the hourly pay has major discrepancies from location to location or even within the same clinic. They will say everyone above them is to blame and they are helpless in order to get more work out of you. You’ll be the lowest paid employee doing the most work. There are no raises unless you opt into doing every job in the clinic. They manipulate you to make you feel like you’re part of the team and they are depending on you so you can keep working insane amounts for minimal pay. And I’d all else fails they will lie to keep you. Pretend that youre going to get a phantom promotion that’s never coming. The managers all talk about each other badly then smile in each others faces, laugh and talk about the employees. It’s a horrible company to work for. HR doesn’t care about anything but protecting HCA. Proof means nothing. You will be yelled at by management and gossiped about amongst your peers who hang out with the manager for perks. It will have you seeking help from a therapist and questioning your own sanity. Just run.

review_title: It's like a lot of jobs right now
pros: Paid time off, overtime, home to a lot of genuinely caring providers
cons: Short staff, long days, not enough pay

review_title: Find a better place to work

pros: Good experience for what never to do, & lots of locations in DFW
cons: Management is absolutely terrible. Regional “managers” on your webex chat that just like the power they have. Share Now proves they care about profit and not people. There’s a reason they are the largest for profit organization. Providers are always NPs or PAs which is fine but call themselves doctors. Misleading to patients. The care given by the back of office staff was embarrassing to be a part of as it was understaffed, lack of proper resources and overall lazy people. The pay is bad too. 14 hour shifts with no break at single coverage locations is ridiculous. With more coverage you can take an unpaid break. Patients always leave angry as the staff does not care and the effort is minimal by all. You get what you pay for. HCA is a joke of a brand and needs to raise their standards to improve care.

pros: They are associated with HCA and St. Davids.
cons: As a medical professional with over a decade of experience, CareNow was one of the worst places to work in the Austin area. They fall short of employee expectations at every level from Front Desk, MA, LMRT, and Providers. Due to lack of support from management there is a very high staff turnover with minimal training for new employees.  At times there are clinics that are expected to function at full capacity with only two staff members.  MA's are expected to do front desk, LMRTs are expected to do MA/Front desk tasks, and providers have to vital/room their own patients. Day to day work environment becomes extremely dangerous when there are high volumes/low staff. There's a ton of red tape from management and every aspect is micromanaged. Management doesn't care to retain their staff. Compensation isn't comparable and extremely low for Austin living. Working 3 days a week/12 hours shifts/one weekend felt like a great deal initially however scheduling is extremely restricted.  If you signed a contract to work for CareNow in Austin, it's not too late, back out. I highly do not recommend working for CareNow in Austin.

job_title: Physician Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Work schedule - 3 days/wk
cons: Long shifts-12+ hrs and inconsistent quitting time

pros: Great bonuses, flex pay, flex hours.
cons: Money over patient care. The bottom line matters than quality care. Focused more on getting patient in and out with little to no regard for quality of care.

pros: Great Co-Workers, flexible schedules, and short work weeks.
cons: Bottom of the barrel pay, bad communication, little respect for individual workers.

job_title: Physician Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Most Coworkers were nice. One in particular was pretty rude and callous and it was very apparent when she was having a bad day, in the way she treated those new learning team members under her charge and the patients.
Nurses are awesome! Docs were very humble and understanding and helpful. Great if you want to work your way up in med field. Benefits were AWESOME ! If you are paid enough to afford them plus your bills.
cons: Hours/schedule constantly changing and all over the place. Example Monday 6a-10pm, Tuesday 3pm-10pm, Thursday 6am-11am, Saturday 11a-4pm. Very difficult if you have children or anything. Pay for the amount of things you’re expected to learn and do daily is not good but I believe that experience and race may factor into play so advocate for yourself and ask if pay can be increased because they will throw a low offer. Can be overwhelming when you are first learning the role. Training did not properly equip or introduce to even 60% of everything that was expected on the job.

pros: Literally no pros to working at this job

They let it get entirely too busy and expect way too much from the staff and providers. You work 15 hour shifts without a break because they are so understaffed. They don’t pay anywhere near the amount they should. I’ve been a medical assistant for 4 years and I get paid $15.00/hour and getting a raise is impossible. DO NOT WORK HERE. Texas Health has an $8k sign on bonus for MAs, go there!

pros: Schedule, job is easy and redundant. Minimum manager presence,  minimum supervision. Great insurance
cons: Everything else. There’s no room for growth, Carenow doesn’t CARE about employees. Gave them 6.5 years, and all I got was a paycheck. Turnover rate is ridiculous. They don’t like to give raises however they hire at a much higher rate than the older employees which is why most of us QUIT.

review_title: Ask yourself "How much is my sanity worth?"
pros:
Pay is decent. 
The benefits aren't bad. 
Bonus (with several strings attached though).
Mind numbingly easy work.
Not challenging.
Will promote to management regardless of qualifications.
Free snacks (junk food)
No need to clock out for lunch.....because you won't have more than 15 minutes to inhale it because the patient volume is so ridiculous. It's even worse for providers because they don't have anyone to cover while they eat so they usually eat at the computer while charting or come back to a bunch of patients waiting to be seen. 

3-12 hr shifts

Lots of OT due to the poor staffing.

You will always get at least 45 mins of OT each night you work because you will have a huge mess to clean up after seeing way more patients than appropriate.

You'll sleep good and hard after you're done fuming when you get home.

I've figured out the fine art of crying while driving home at night.
cons:
POOR staffing. 

It will be you, a radiology tech, and 1 provider. That's it. You will see 40-75 patients a day and upper management will say that's not enough patients to justify even an additional provider let alone a front desk person. 

They have been telling us for MONTHS that they are hiring additional staff but no one has shown up yet. Now they claim that they have made offers but that it will take a month or more to get them cleared and trained because of the "pandemic". 

Some ee's will bicker like children and management won't address it because they're lazy.

Job duties are very BLURRED. You will be told when you interview that you'll help the front desk for breaks, but what they mean is you will work the front desk for half of the day, and then the radiology tech will work the front and you will go to the back to bring patients back. Management will come out and help you when you tell them to but will find an excuse to go back in their office and close the door.

Management constantly says they're "hiring" people but they always seem to end up at another clinic or the hiring process takes super long.

Clinic management is not very intelligent and generally lazy. Most of the time when I ask my CM about something I'm unsure about they have to call the other CM at another location who has some idea of what's going on. 

The manager literally shows up to work and then leaves to get breakfast every morning even though we're drowning in patients and have no staff.

The manager will say "I'm running to the bank" or "I have to run errands" and is gone for 2 hours while we're running like crazy.

Management will get on you about doing callbacks to patients even though there is no time and then you will find them playing games on their phone while you're running about trying not to pee your pants.

They're super excited about COVID because it's "good for business"...such a disgusting remark that came from management.

Patients treat you like garbage and that's totally ok.

Radiology techs should not be triaging patients. CM's should not be triaging patients (unless they're a nurse which I haven't seen yet always an MA or RT-). Nurses and Providers should triage patients.

If you pride yourself on providing quality patient care this is not the place for you.

The only time the patient volume is decent is when there is a surge in COVID patients, otherwise, there are days where you wonder how much longer the clinic will be open. They're desperately trying to make a name for themselves in a saturated market where they have no clout except that they will make their staff see any patient even if it puts the patient at risk and the clinical staff says it's unsafe.

There's no actual staff support or appreciation and it shows.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Overland Park, KS
pros:
Fast paced,  so it keeps you busy.
Great coworkers
Immediate manager is wonderful
Training is pretty decent
cons:
There is a huge lack of front desk (patient access rep.) getting an actual lunch break, to the point of almost not getting to eat until towards the end of your 12 hour shift.

Wait time for patients is almost always 45 minutes or longer and corporate/upper management seem to not want to make a staffing change to fix the issue. Instead PAR is expected to update patients every 10 mins as if that will help the wait time decrease.

Underpaid, majorly. For a corpoation that brings in as many paitents and money as it does you would think they would pay their empoloyees better.  PAR is told they are the face, the first person a patient see's or talks to that starts the experince that should be good. However PAR's are underappreciated and underpaid for what they are expected to do.

review_title: Personal feelings of an exceptional employer.
job_title: ARNP-FNP in Port St Lucie, FL
pros: Well funded, competetive wages with growth potential.
cons: Comments reserved, Con's are subjective to an individuals perception.

pros: I love what I do and I love the clinical staff at the Allen, TX clinic. Truly an amazing team that I had the privilege and honor to work with. All are extremely hard working and dedicated.
cons:
The CareNow in Allen TX  is poorly managed and improperly staffed.  The patient volume overwhelmes the clinic when it is run on single coverage at almost all times. The front desk staff is one person expected to check in and check out all patients as well as handle the never ending phone calls and walk in patients.  The nursing staff is non stop between patient rooms, triage, rooming new patients, calling web checkinsand call backs.  The staff rarely gets a moment to eat lunch much less the a bathroom break. 12 + hours days with no lunch break and maybe 1 bathroom break. I have been to other clinics and it is not this way.  The staff is a revolving door because of the way the clinic is managed. 

Schedules are a thing of the past at this clinic. A schedule is posted but the manager is constantly changing it, cutting back your hours and not informing you.  Txts, calls and emails almost daily asking me to come in early or fill in at other clinics.  If you have a significant other, a spouse, children, or a life outside of your job this is not a place you want to be employed!

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Dallas, TX

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Mansfield, TX

review_title: They require your "full time". You no longer have family time when you become a manager .
pros: You leave with a lot of experience. You see all different types of patients.
cons: The company requires staff to bend over backwards for the patients and for them but they don't do the same for you. Upper management has no clue what it's like to manage at the Center Manager level as they were managers 10 + years ago when the job was no where near as time consuming and the company was much smaller. They sugar coat everything and act like they care about you on a personal level but you find out quickly that they really don't care about their employees, especially the managers. That's why they keep burning through them. The pay is nowhere near worth the job discription (which is 7 pages btw). But you'll see that there is a HUGE pay gal between upper and lower management. They drive Lexus's and BMW's while we struggle to pay our bills. The work is constant. You take it home even if you stay an hour and a half late. Your family time goes out the window because you constantly have to watch wait times and make phone calls or send text messages. There are always open shifts. You have to spend hours calling the doctor phone list to find coverage. They are write-up happy beyond reason.  BEWARE. This job is awful.

job_title: Patient Care Representative in Garland, TX
pros: They privided a descent amount of income
cons: Hectic work environment, short- staff, crazy hours.

pros: Good shedule. If you are willing to work more hours, you can make more money. (Unlike a salaried position.)  The patients were, for the most part, friendly and courteous, they frequently expressed appreciation for my care and for the extended hours.
cons: Critical, bullying superiors. Constant criticism and incessant reprimands. Very tight restrictions on your practice. If you are a maverick, this place is not for you. Everything you do is to protect the company from getting sued. If you are a human being whom occasionally makes mistakes, this place is not for you. Forget everything you've learned over the years! CareNow has protocols to be followed and any deviation will be reprimanded. Management doesn't listen to your concerns. When I tried to quit, they threatened me with "severe consequences." I ultimately had to get myself fired to get out of that toxic work environment.

pros: mostly good people at the clinic level, variety of experiences gained on the job
cons:
seriously deceptive corporate model, incompetent upper middle management, toxic culture, unhappy employees, extremely litigious workplace.
I hired on with the expectation of fulfilling their mission statement to glorify God through quality care. as the weeks became months and so forth, I noticed that the emphasis was far more about quantity rather than quality. I was "urged" to see patients in less than 7 minutes, this is because I had 6 or 7 collateral duties and they weren't going to staff the people needed. when I asked how rushing the elderly was "glorifying God" I got an up-beat, patronizing response.  then the write ups came. I have never had my character so maligned as when i worked for this "Christian" company. Basically when they write you up make sure you have an attorney present. 
CareNow has become the Goliath it pretends to oppose. if you go to work for them watch out.

review_title: Don't work here until they change
pros: None. Literally. The co workers are nice.
cons: No breaks, terrible pay, terrible schedule, micromanaged. There is no value placed on employees. They take away hours and move your schedule with little notice, nothing is set in stone and ask you to leave work all the time with no compensation which leaves your check short. Then if it gets busy, you're short staffed and have to deal with patients waiting a long time and getting angry. During the busy season, they expect you to work more and more citing that employees should expect this and be thankful after having short hours during the slow season. The pay is sub-par and administration micromanages everything so there is redundancy and inefficiency. Their turn over rate is high, but they don't want to make the changes and invest in human capital, which is their most valuable asset. Without human capital, they would not have a business. Their management and organizational flow is antiquated and has not kept up with the social changes and values of today, which has left their culture with nothing but bitterness and a hard lesson of what they do not want when they immediately start applying to a new prospective employer.

job_title: Area Practice Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
I took some time to think about how I want to word this review. 

- Teams are great and helpful
- Providers are amazing for the most part and care about the teams 
 - You can be promoted if you fight hard
- The Las Vegas HR team does their best with the mess of a market manager they have to deal with
cons:
- As a leader, you have no say in the direction of your practice
- Getting a teammate a 20 cent raise is about as difficult as getting someone at a normal company a $50,000 raise
- The payscales are a mess, and they will willingly pay anyone as low as possible
- If you plan on being in leadership here, prepare to have your phone ring for 20 hours a day for like $40,000 a year
- You have to fight on your own behalf because your leaders likely can’t do anymore than you can. Even the president can’t get anyone raises. 
- Leaving CareNow, your pay will likely be doubled or more

pros: Flexible scheduling to a certain extent.  The Doctors and PA's are awesome.  The ability to work at other clinics or switch shifts with any employee throughout the company.
cons: Employees are treated like a number; high turnover rate due to being scheduled 32 hours and no OT allowed until someone calls in or no show for shifts at the last minute.  No support or teamwork  from  management. Work overload due to lack of coverage focusing on numbers, budgets, efficiencies which decreases the customer service being given/seen by patients. Favoritism, promotion is prevented for some based off of if you have some way rubbed upper management the wrong was vs. performance based.

pros: If you can make it there... you can make it anywhere. They hire GVN's and GN's. Bonuses. Nice weekend shift diffs.
cons: The environment is toxic. Management are cluless corporate puppets. Even when you're off... you're not off. Why complain, no one is listening. Turnover rate is super high. If you have any emergency short of death, your job is on the line if YOU can't FIND your own COVERAGE. Unrealistic expectations of daily  nurse duties.

pros: Love the clinic staff,  patients are awesome,
cons: Management is cult like.  Treat employees very bad.  There is never enough staff to get the job done correctly.  They put too much emphasis on speed and not quality care.  You are exptected to work 15 hours with no breaks.  Benefi package lacks.  Even if you earn vacation time its impossible to get approved to use your vacation time.

pros:
Good place to get some experience. 
Good pay, but not a livable wage if you have a family or are the only support in the family. Better than not having a job though. 
Opportunities to move up are there, but its all in management. 
CareNow is owned by HCA a big corporation which owns all Medical city hospitals. So it will be good to work for this company if you are planning on becoming a RN or moving to a hospital. 
Great benefits. they have affordable  healthcare plans (3 levels), help with tuition, and loan repayment.
cons:
High work flow
Limited Providers
Sometimes you work till midnight (depends on the Provider) 
Not enough coverage.

review_title: I just suggest you don't bother.
pros: Insurance but way over priced.
cons: Management and employees only like you if you are snobby and stuck up like they are. They gossip about the patients that they are there to take care of and help get better. An if you are one to stand up for what you believe in don't apply here. They will set you up for failure. They purposely set me. There was nothing I could do to prove it. I didn't have the money to take a big company to court.

review_title: WE ARE IN 2013 PLEASE WAKE UP AND SMELL THE COFFEE STOP MAKING SOOOOO MANY PEOPLE SO MISERABLE
pros: Worked mostly morning shifts. . We got paid a bonus for writing people up and firing people.  That's what it felt like plus everyone has to keep kissing upper management A $$ to receive that bonus
cons: Got paid for 40 hrs but usually worked 70-80 hrs a week because it was busy and had to help the staff after completing my own job since we couldn't pay any overtime or we are always short staffed. Very difficult to find someone that wants to stay and work here

pros: The coworkers are decent to work with and the benefits are good
cons: Underpay, underpay, underpay! I can’t express that enough they expect you to do so many task with just 12$ an hour! You have to answer the phones, do the faxes, do call backs, check in patients, check out patients all while having a patient in front of you. They are understaff so you’re basically by yourself. To top it all off you have management breathing down your neck instead of helping you with the patients that are constantly walking through the doors! The pay has even gotten worse they removed the differential to only $2 extra on the weekends! What a joke! Not to mention they expect you to work 14-15hr days and you still never reach your 40hrs a week this place is draining!

review_title: Patient care is not a priority
pros: Hourly pay, clinic staff is very friendly, extra pay for evenings and weekends, ability to move up within the company, great benefits at HCA facilities, flexible hours
cons: Upper management doesn't care about employee satisfaction, always understaffed, way too much paperwork for patients and staff (all paper, no EMR), never get off when scheduled, inconsistent schedules, "efficiencies" come before patient care, it's all about money.

job_title: Patient Care Representative in Keller, TX
pros: The shift differential is nice. Typically works with school schedule. Will hire without experience.
cons:
This company was bought out a couple years ago and everything has changed. They over work you constantly. When the doors close at 9 we are still here till midnight most nights. They cut our staffing in half so we have to do double the work for the same pay. The patients constantly yell at the front desk for things management wont fix. 
There isnt another company that will start out pay and hire you with no experience AND work with school schedules. So youre pretty much held hostage at this job. 

Gone to management and corporate multiple times and nobody will listen nor help. 

The only options are to suck it up or quit.

review_title: great job for a doctor if you are a good employee
pros: Company actively strives to provide quality medicine, great customer service to patients.  Great pay and benefits for doctors, the best in the dallas-fort worth, tx area.  Holds all employees to same quality standard.  Expectations for employees are clearly stated when you are hired regarding quality medicine and showing up on time.
cons: Occasionally, but rarely, newly hired doctors are constantly tardy, sometimes don't come to work at all, and practice very poor medicine and have to be fired.  Some of those fired doctors then write negative comments about CareNow that are false.

pros: If you don't have much, or any experience they will still hire, and train you.
cons: Very very fast paced. Difficult to learn and keep up at the same time. If you cant keep up, you can rest assured someone is going to be talking about you behind your back.  It's hard to get someone to cover your shift is an emergency comes up, and no matter the circumstances you have to work your shift until someone else is able to get there (family emergency, sick, ect)

pros:
Good benefits through united healthcare, 401k, dental, and vision. 

The attire is easy, just scrubs. 

Occasional (rare) catered lunches on the morning shift.
cons:
Ever since the HCA buyout, CareNow has changed. It used to heavily center around patient care and doing what's best for the patient. Now all they care about are numbers. Patients are just figures on a gauge. Bonuses are all providers care about. 

If you have a family, you'll never see them. Carenow refuses to work with your schedule. It even sent out a memo recently that basically said you can request time off, or give schedule preferences, but it won't be honored and pto can be denied for any reason. I've had to put off going back to school for three semesters because carenow won't work with me. 

The rules and policies constantly change. You get yelled at constantly for breaking rules you had no idea existed, because they were just created that day. They can't make their minds up about anything. 

I don't know about other positions, but front desk is underpaid. They try to make up for it by having differential payment on certain shifts but it still doesn't make up what you're losing. And forget about overtime. I had 3 hours of overtime on my last check so they cut my hours this week. If you pick up a shift at another clinic your hours will get cut at your home clinic to get you as few hours as possible. 

Severely, painfully understaffed. When asking management why we cant get additional coverage on very busy days, we were told that we get "lazy" when there's adequate coverage. Which is wholly untrue. Just because your staff isn't running around losing their minds does not mean they are lazy. They can't keep employees and the turnover rate is huge. I've been with Carenow for 16 months and not once in that time has my front desk been adequately staffed to meet patient need. I often have to stay an hour and a half to two hours after my shift multiple days a week just to get what needs to be done, done. They expect us to do too much in too little time. Furthermore, this year they decided to make a new position at the corporate office, so one person makes the schedules for all of the patient reps in the whole division instead of allowing it to be on a clinic to clinic basis like it always has been, and it's resulted in chaos. There are so many open shifts, they have no idea what they're doing because they weren't carenow employees, they are outside hires so they have no clue how the scheduling should work. 

The equipment is ALWAYS malfunctioning. They have started buying clinics these copier/scanners that don't scan. They'll act like they scan but the information doesn't get sent, which negatively affects us because then we get a 500 chart list of charts that need to be found, pulled, rescanned, out back together, and put away. The computers break down constantly and are so, so painfully slow. Yell at us about efficiency all you want but we can only go as fast as our computer. The id/insurance scanners don't work and are also so slow it's faster and more reliable to make a photocopy on the barely functional copier.  

Front desk employees are treated with very little respect. They have a positive/negative log which keeps track of the employees, but I have never once seen a positive written down. They only care about the negative. You can have the best costumer service in the world and be praised by multitudes of patients, but that will never get written down. Few minutes late? You can bet it's logged even if it's in the "grace period" you have to be considered on time. 

The company is so concentrated on expanding that they let the clinics they already have go completely ignored. Our machines don't work, we can't get IT out to fix anything, they're completely out of touch with us.

job_title: Patient Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros: You learn a lot, training is very well done, flexible schedules, great bonuses (if you qualify for them), and a real sense of comradely between the other members of the clinic.
cons: Low, low, low pay ($2-$4 lower than their competitors), and upper management really doesn't understand what it's like to be "in the trenches," so to speak.  They demand things that are impossible to do and simply have no grasp of what it's like to work at the clinic level.

review_title: Be Smart. Get a Full Time Job Somewhere Else, Providers, and Work Here Part Time
pros: Always need part time providers, especially on weekends and holidays, good pay, extremely easy work (mostly allergies, a few lacerations).
cons:
Do not take a full time job as a provider if you also plan to have a life.   

More importantly, the business model (which I will not disclose) means that providers are constantly being pressured to compromise professionalism, and their licenses are put at risk.

pros: The only pro was my coworkers at the time and figuring out the red flags that were there and leaving when I did.
cons: Severely understaffed, the pay is low, management is nonexistent and never around, you will never get out on time or even close. Be prepared to never get a lunch or restroom break. Over worked.

pros: Pay is good. Full time doctors and all clinic staff is great for the most part, very good employees
cons: Corporate office, constant new memos, constant audits/clinic reviews. They care more about patient wait times, clinic numbers etc than the actual care that is being given. The wrong people are promoted. Not enough staff allowed, plenty of prn staff wanting hours but shifts are not created.

pros: Compensation, free medical care for employees at clinics
cons: Obsession about metrics/numbers, overworked employees, medical care outside of standard guidelines (overtesting and overtreating), company proclaims to value God but actually cares more about making money

pros:
decent hours.
nurses and doctors are extremely nice. 
time goes by pretty fast.
cons:
if you aren't moving quick enough for them they get upset.
unfriendly and childish patient reps. 
terrible training. They expect you to learn a huge packet of their beliefs and acronyms along with the actual job which is a lot to handle. So basically your thrown to the wolves. 
No breaks.
Messing up one thing can slow down production.
A lot of stress is placed upon patient reps to answers phones, greet customers, handle online check ins in a timely manner, filing, and verifying benefits.
Random quizzes from home office over the huge packet of manual.

pros: People with good intentions trying to take care of patients the best they can.  Very bright nurses.
cons: Quarterly bonus barely compensates for low wages, typically hire new grads or under qualified individuals to work them like dogs and not pay industry standard,  arbitrary metrics determine bonus which ultimately undermines the quality of patient care, middle management ineffective and often uneducated,  upper management out of tune with clinic environment and really want Carenow to be the McDonald's of health care - serve as many as possible to make as much as possible even if care is substandard.

pros: Engaged team that cares about your progress and success.  We are growing fast but have been able to stay humble and keep consistency despite growth.  President is awesome as are the two current Vice Presidents of Ops.
cons: Have to be an owner.  If you don't want to lead and be a part of a quickly changing organization, this might not be the right fit.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Overland Park, KS
pros: Benefits.  3 day work weeks.
cons: Being bullied by your coworkers, providers, manager, upper management and human resourses! You will have absolutely nobody to go to! The bullying you see on TV, has nothing on Carenow! I wouldn't recommend my worse enemy to this place! I can definely understand the mind of someone wanting to take their own life after working at Carenow in Kansas!

pros: Flexible schedule if you want to work weekends or if you want to work at other clinics you can also go
cons: MICROMANAGED!!!! Absolutely ridiculous expectations. NO BREAKS AND NO LUNCH TIME

pros: Advancement Opportunities are endless. You can easily score a center manager position with hard work and dedication. The benefits are also really great!
cons: Hardly uses nursing skills. If you're looking to use your skills and become a stronger nurse, then working here is probably not for you. A Medical Assistant can do the LVN's job, unfortunately.

review_title: Clinic staff works hard; corporate staff does not
job_title: Lab/X-ray Tech in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The clinical staff truly cares about the patients that they see. Staff works very hard with some very long hours and some very sick (angry) patients. Still, the job is rewarding and very interesting. I had some of the best co-workers on the planet.
cons: The heads of the company are pompous, arrogant, and don't care about their clinical staff.

pros: Plenty of Over Time to work.
cons: Understaffed Overworked Favoritism ,Underpaid.Overlooked, Unappreciated.

job_title: Patient Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Awesome co-workers
Flexibility to work either 8 hour shifts or 14-16 hour shifts
FDC and CM are usually really understanding
cons:
Upper management 
Short staffed
Policies are made by individuals who haven't worked in the actual clinic, so policies sometimes don't make sense

review_title: Do not waste your time here
pros: I have met some amazing people here. And if you are looking for experience it's a good way to get your foot in the door. But that's it.
cons: I worked at the corporate office in the billing department. The upper management is extremely unprofessional. They are opening clinics left and right but not hiring any more staff. They are opening clinics in other states but not researching state laws. They are opening clinics before setting up contracts with insurance companies which is a headache for patients and the employees.  They are putting the billing team in empty offices with tiny desks because "there aren't enough cubicles". Even though there are several empty cubicles. They have 4-8 people packed in rooms. The lead micromanages and will follow you around the building. I couldn't go to the bathroom or break room without her following me. They give you a ridiculous work load. I was the only one in my department and had been asking for help for ten months. Management didn't care until the CEO noticed and all of the sudden it's their #1 priority. However, they still didn't help they just started micromanaging even more. I finally had enough and put my 2 weeks in. 2 days after they had created a new team of 6-8 people to do the job I had been doing all by myself. They do not care about quality work just quantity. This is resulting in dissatisfied employees and patients. They do not care about their employees. There is an extremely high turnover rate. The pay is below average. They do not care about the staff at the clinics either. I transferred from the clinic hoping this would be better but it's just the same. All they care about is money.

review_title: CareNow is a good company to work for, however, poor management, and near impossible efficiency goals.
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Grapevine, TX
pros: Competitive base pay, as well as night and weekend differential.
cons: They are focused heavily on efficiencies, and that takes away a large portion of the bonus if your clinic does not do well. CareNow is also notorious for hiring unqualified managers, and there is a lot of turnover among the staff.

pros: Good pay... They are pretty good at only hiring the best nurses so you will not be working with idiots...
cons: Some of the doctors mostly the NP and PA's can be less than top flight

pros: Good staff, variety of patients. Easy scheduling, competitive pay with good benefits.  Locations are similar moving to other clinics is a smooth transition to fill in.  Overall a good experience.
cons: Long hours, lots of memos and policy changes. Personal time off limited during the flu season.  During lull periods managers to quick to send people home.

pros: Some of the staff can be great! As with anywhere!
cons:
We found out they have been calculating OT incorrectly paying only over 40hrs/week instead of each 12 hour+ shift like CO state LAW requires. Corporate was pissed when when they found out and said they will be doing an audit of paystubs. PLUS they offer a 16% shift differential for PRN employees, but you better check your paystubs because they don't pay it. Shady nickel-and-dimers. But still always running out of supplies! 
Incredibly low morale due to constant high expectations. Work comp, employee health- drug screens/physicals, urgent care walk-ins, and Covid tests out the wazoo!  Trying to keep the visit, and wait times at a minimum (under 45min from door to door), but volumes up, doesn't make sense. One is going to suffer. We are humans, and for quality care, things take time. You can't have both every minute of every day.  Add in the fact that Covid tests are coming in from web check-in, telehealth, and walk-in daily, what do you expect?! Thankfully, often times there will be an front desk, MA, and RT working, but RT's don't help the MA's much, and are thrown into the front desk here and there with very little training. Ridiculous demands.
HCA has a history of treating their employees awfully, blatant lies, and shady dealings with the pay you work hard to earn. I'd do yourself a favor, and keep looking. You deserve better.

pros: Pay is decent, can  be seen at any CareNow for free besides the one you are employed at.
cons:
-work/life balance inadequate
-do not appreciate their employees
-make you feel obligated to pick up other shifts at different locations
-can not call in without finding someone to pick your shift up
-said I would only have to work every other weekend but I was working every weekend

pros: Staff members, PTO, Usually plenty on OT
cons: Overworked and underpaid, understaffed. Wants to charge as an urgent care facility but wants to see patients as a PCP.

pros: 12 hour shifts, three day work weeks, co workers friendly, bonuses are nice if you can make the scores to meet them.
cons: Having to see high volume of patients with only one provider, no opportunity for advancement. Upper level management not approachable, only care for patient satisfaction...not employee satisfaction.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Garland, TX
pros: It's a great place to get experience towards an office job or receptionist position.
cons: The manager I worked under was rude and did not want to foster employees to be better unless it went towards her bonus.

job_title: Patient Representative in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: Flexible schedule, bonuses, friendly coworkers, free medical treatment at the facility for employee and spouse/dependent, and variable rate payment system.
cons: Horrible operating hours, very low compensation for work completed, lack of upward mobility within the company, management incompetent, employees treated poorly throughout the company.

review_title: It’s okay. It’s not all cake and ice cream
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Dallas, TX
pros: You get to pick up at other clinics for over time.
cons: During the pandemic we were not protected and appreciated like we should have and it can be a overload.

job_title: Patient Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
-decent pay
-Clean Facilities 
-Decently organized office/clinic
-Knowledgable providers and nurses
-Patients treated very well
cons:
-inconsistent hours and schedule that changes constantly 
-Large separation of management and clinic staff
-huge work load in fast paced environment 
-bad hours
-corporate 
-office equipment often broken/unusable 
-good luck scoring overtime at your home clinic they will send you home only to call you back in or leave you on call.

pros: Decent pay and offers good benefits.
cons: No breaks, constantly harassed to work all the time. Some management is terrible and very unprofessional. They do not value their employees. its all about money!

review_title: Extremely laid back not a stressful environment at all.
pros: Coworkers & patients of all ages
cons: You never know what will walk through the door at any given time?  Broken bones stitches etc.

pros: Coworkers are amazing and everyone in the clinics work together.
cons: Upper management needs to be refurbished!

pros: Talented caring coworkers at clinic level.
cons: Upper management shows disregard for efforts

review_title: It was an experiences which was not focused around patient care.
pros: You get to see a variety of patients
cons: The patient relationship expectation is below the norm.    The hours are unpredicable and hard.

pros: To many openings and schedules are good
cons:
I was treated by the management as I was there slave and I was disrespected
Paper charts are very disorganized

job_title: Patient Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros: staff, shift differential, gained knowledge, flexibility
cons: HOURS, NO BREAKS, MANAGEMENT, No max for patient walk-ins, wait times

pros: Good pay, good differentials, quarterly bonuses.
cons: Management was hard, you get "graded" on documentation.

pros: Great hours, professional, good benefits
cons: Not enough pay, difficult to get a hold of manager at times

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Las Vegas, NV
pros: The three days a week work week is nice
cons: Everything you do is timed, all they are about is getting patients in and out

pros: Chill environment at slower clinics
cons: Busy clinics are crazy and can’t keep people in management positions so everything is unorganized. R

pros: Decent pay with differential on weekends/evenings.
cons: Gets very repetitive. You have an increased chance of getting sick.

pros: 100 % profit oriented. Never seen this kind of model with so much greed.
cons: Worst place for Physicians to work. No respect for MD's. Nice system to bully Physician's through Physician's(in Management)

pros:
Good compensation
Good support staff
Nice facility
cons: This is a very busy urgent care clinic.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: Fast paced and lots to learn.
cons: Payscale and (at the time) management practices.

pros: great company culture and opportunities for advancement
cons: high stress environment most of the time.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Westlake Village, CA
pros: 12 hour shifts are good
cons: low pay what they claim is market rate

pros: Good people, professional and clean.
cons: Haven’t had any issues yet.

pros: Tons of work!!! Never any downtime! Project after project! Day goes by FAST!!
cons: Tons of work!! Little pay!! No appreciation!

pros: good weekend pay and flexible hours
cons: management was awful. monthly reviews were awful
